title: Before 16 February 2018, will President Trump sign legislation that reduces the top marginal federal corporate tax rate?
possible_answers: Yes, to a rate of 20% or less
Yes, to a rate greater than 20% but less than 25%
Yes, to a rate of 25% or greater
correct_answer: Yes, to a rate greater than 20% but less than 25%
preds: His economic plans are contingent on American money moving back to USA
The answer is now obvious given that the President has already signed the bill into law, but I just now came across this question

Updating my previous forecast on account of the bill passing the House earlier today. Barring any GOP defections in the Senate, or some unforeseen event, it appears to be almost a certainty that President Trump will sign the bill which lowers the top marginal federal corporate tax rate to 21 percent.
All GOP senators have now said they will vote for the bill. McCain is sick and will miss the vote but still gives GOP a 51-48 margin.

Switching to 100% for >20 <25 as it is now set to be 21% not 20, but we never know with Trumpet.  Also claimed in campaign to reduce brackets from 7 to 3 (as if that really is a good thing. That's not the reason why the tax code is complex).

I am updating my previous forecast on account of the news that John McCain is going back to Arizona and will not be voting on the tax bill this coming week. The GOP can afford to lose one vote now and still pass the bill, so I still believe that it is quite likely that it will pass. Additionally, it has been said that, if necessary, McCain will return to D.C. to vote on the bill. All that being said, I believe the bill is less likely to pass in light of this news.

Given that Senator Rubio and Senator Corker recently announced their support for the current tax bill--which sets the top marginal federal corporate tax rate at 21 percent-- it seems highly likely that President Trump will sign the current tax bill before the end of the year.  I believe there is a remote chance that the negotiations between the House and Senate breakdown will cause a vote on the bill to be delayed to 2018. And, if so, the bill will become slightly more difficult to pass given that Doug Jones will be seated by that time. That said, I put the odds at the bill passing after February 16 or not at all at 1 in 20. Lastly, although I don't believe that it is very likely that the rate in the current bill changes before it passes, I don't think it is impossible, either. Congressmen who want a lower rate could potentially negotiate to get the rate to 20 percent of lower. Likewise, I do not think it is out of the question that the rate is increased, potentially to prevent the bill from adding more that 1.5 trillion to the deficit over the next ten years to abide by Senate rules. Therefore, I gave each outcome a 1 percent chance of taking place.

Dateline 12-14-2017 Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) threatened Thursday to vote against Republicans’ $1.5 trillion tax overhaul unless it further expands a child tax credit to millions of working families, leaving GOP leaders searching for answers on a final deal that had appeared to be on the verge of sailing through the House and Senate. Rubio, along with Sen. Mike Lee (R-Utah), wants Republican leaders to include the expansion as they reconcile separate tax measures passed by the House and Senate, working to craft a final compromise bill that could pass both chambers and be sent President Trump for his signature. -- https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/rubio-to-vote-against-gop-tax-bill-unless-tax-credit-for-working-poor-is-expanded/2017/12/14/8be53a22-e0f9-11e7-89e8-edec16379010_story.html

Pondering how the conference committee may resolve the differences in the 2 bills. Here are some add backs that have been publicized with varying costs assigned depending on the source. The cost of the cuts keep increasing and the Byrd rules still apply. If one assumes that the healthcare mandate stays repealed, there is one estimate. If they dump the repeal of the mandate which I assume they will do, there is a second estimate. What do you all think? Some of the add backs (because we don't really know) assuming they DUMP the ACA mandate repeal:
1)Alternative minimum tax corporate - House wants full repeal = + 40B
2) Corporate debt payments = +136B
3) Allow state and local income taxes to be deducted above Senate version of only a limit of 10,000 for property taxes = +148B
4) Don't repeal the ACA mandate (as the Senate version did) = + 348B Not sure what else they're thinking ( full repeal of the estate tax?) but the above alone  = 672 Billion If the conference committee retains the repeal of the ACA mandate in the bill, then they need to come up with (324 Billion) more to fill -- but they have political complications, especially with Susan Collins and other Senators that are much harder to deal with than moving numbers around. Don't think they're going to pass those healthcare bills to keep Susan Collins so they'll have to remove the mandate repeal to get her vote anyway. So far, we're looking at an estimate of finding $324B or $672B to make it work.  Consider adding back 2% to the corporate tax rate cut making it 22% = equals $200 - 400 billion dependent on how they score it.. I'm guessing they score it on the higher end.  So, the question remains, will they increase the corporate tax rate to 22%? I think they will but it will be the very last thing that they do so that the floodgates to more things are closed. Current corporate tax rate in the Senate and the House versions are 20%. There are talks of increasing it to 21% and Pres. Trump did say that he's still OK with 22%. The House will vote on the motion of accepting the Senate version as-is on Monday (I'll have to double check it means today Dec 4 or Monday Dec 11).  So here are the odds:
The tax rate remains at 20% if:
1. (a) The House will accept the Senate version as-is to avoid conference [50%] AND
    (b) done it before the end of the year [80% chance since there is plenty of time and only involve the House] AND 
   (c) President Trump has no objection [100%, he already voiced his support, as is] AND 
   (d) President Trump signs it [98%] OR
2. (a) House chose to go to conference [50%] AND 
(b) The rate remains at 20% in the consolidated bill [60%] AND 
(c) both Chambers passes the consolidated bill [80%] AND 
(d) done before then end of the year [50%] AND 
(e) President Trump doesn't object to the final bill [95%, there could be chances something new creeps up into the final bill that Trump doesn't like and don't underestimate the Republicans' ability to fumble] AND 
(f) Trump physically signs it [98%] The following is the Odd of between 20.1% and 25%: 
3. (a) House chose to go to conference [50%] AND 
(b) The rate is adjusted above 20% in the consolidated bill [40%] AND 
(c) both Chambers passes the consolidated bill [80%] AND 
(d) done before then end of the year [50%] AND 
(e) President Trump doesn't object to the final bill [95%, there could be chances something new creeps up into the final bill that Trump doesn't like and don't underestimate the Republicans' ability to fumble] AND 
(f) Trump physically signs it [98%] Odds for the rate higher than 25% is null, since neither House nor Senate nor the White House talk of anything above 22%. ODD:S

Taking a bit of a defensive position on the rate. Republicans will need a lot of money in the reconciliation talks, and Trump unexpectedly signaled flexibility on the rate up to 22 percent. Moreover, the Senate version has the cut only from 2019, while the House has it from 2018.  A 22 percent rate from 2018 could be a possible compromise.

Obviously, the GOP is hellbent on achieving some form of legislative victory before the 2018 campaign really kicks off. With that said, there's still some significant hurdles to overcome for the tax bill to be signed by Feb 16. First is the amount of time to get the work done. The Senate has 38 days (assuming the same work schedule as 2017 since they haven't published their 2018 calendar) and the House has 28. The House and Senate now need to go to conference and reconcile the differences between the two bills, which could be more difficult than the GOP would like to admit. Additionally, the conference bill would have to pass another "Byrd bath" by the Senate Parliamentarian, which limits some of the flexibility in the negotiations. Second, the WH seems to think a government shutdown would be a good thing, and the Dems are signalling they would be willing to oblige Trump on this issue. While unrelated to the tax bill, it could consume the better part of December and potentially January, especially if its just a series of stopgap bills. That would consume floor debate time, committee time, and negotiating time to keep the government open or to reopen, as a shutdown while controlling both houses and the WH is probably not a look the GOP would like to have. Thus, the looming threat of shutdown could push tax reform outside the window of this Question. Finally, don't discredit the possibility of Trump derailing efforts through some new distraction or debacle that requires Congressional action (actions against North Korea or Iran, starting a new conflict somewhere under the guise of AUMF, etc.). This could insert unnecessary delay into the tax process, putting it beyond the Feb 16 deadline for the Q. What the GOP does have going for it is the heating up of the Mueller investigation, and the tightening of the net around WH officials. I'm sure the GOP leadership is painfully aware of that, and is likely motivated to get tax reform done prior to any major developments that could incapacitate WH leadership. In that regard, the faster they go, the more warning signs they blow past, and the more procedural steps they ignore along the way, the more likely it is they achieve their goal of passing legislation. While in the long term this is an extremely shortsighted way to reshape the US economy, with the consequences (intended or unintended) lasting for years, it is the most effective way to prevent defections within the GOP or an organized response by external entities, thus improving the odds of success. I think the GOP will pass some form of tax reform. It's almost inevitable for them, especially since they've been able to bring on the holdouts. What I'm less confident about is getting it done by Feb 16, especially when a shutdown could further lessen the precious few legislative days both chambers have before that deadline. If Congress can pass a long term CR, then the path is essentially cleared of major legislative obstacles. So watch what happens over the next week (the current CR expires Dec 8), and the weeks following if Congress can only achieve a stopgap measure or if a shutdown occurs.

I don't expect the House to pass the Senate version of the bill and believe it goes to conference committee to negotiate the differences in the two bills. I don't see the House increasing the corporate tax rate but they may not want to delay it as the Senate version delays its implementation till 2019. The House version makes individual tax cuts permanent while they sunset in the Senate version. The House wants to repeal the estate tax entirely. Whatever the House decides to restore in their version costs money and increases the deficit.

https://www.politico.com/story/2017/11/28/schumer-pelosi-cancel-meeting-with-trump-262853
"House and Senate Democratic leaders on Tuesday abruptly withdrew from a scheduled White House meeting about averting a government shutdown after President Donald Trump publicly slammed them and cast doubt on the negotiations. Trump tweeted early Tuesday that House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) "want illegal immigrants flooding into our Country unchecked, are weak on Crime and want to substantially RAISE Taxes," adding, "I don’t see a deal!" Pelosi and Schumer responded by canceling their plans to meet with Trump and GOP leaders to discuss a deal to keep the government open, raising the prospects of a shutdown as government funding expires next week." This is the 'win' President Trump wants but there are many other broader issues that are likely to deny him this because the political damage would for many be worth the risk.

For those interested, the Senate should have 43 legislative days to achieve this (assuming they work a schedule similar to the beginning of 2017), and the House has 33 days (https://www.majorityleader.gov/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/2018-Annual.pdf).  In that time, they need to keep the government functioning, and have not put forth much effort trying to reach across the aisle on issues like DACA, raising the sequestration caps, stabilizing the ACA markets, or even taxes. It would not take a lot of effort by the Dems to blow up the tax plan schedule by shutting down the government and forcing the GOP to the negotiation table. And that doesn't even get into the effects the Senate Parliamentarian could have on shaping the tax bill by determining which parts do or do not meet reconciliation procedures and are thus eligible or not to be included in the final bill. And that will add time to the schedule that no one seems to be accounting for. The complexities of Congress, and perhaps its dysfunction, should not be overlooked just because the notional topic of tax reform has broad appeal to the GOP. The devil is in the details, as the GOP (should have) learned from trying to repeal ACA.

For legislators, 20% may just be the opening gambit. It's a great distraction, with the failing dotard at 39% approval they desperately need a win. I'm assuming theocrat pedo Roy Moore (or a GOP Senator) takes over Russian-stooge AG Jeff Sessions' Alabama seat.

This is a key issue for the GOP to show that the election to a majority in Congress would result in some legislative campaign promises being met.  Obviously if Congress passes such a reduction Trump will sign it.  The question is will Congress pass it.  Politically they should and therefore there should be a bill for Trump to sign.  Do Flake, Johnson, Crocker or MaCain really care anymore about the GOP agenda or do they care more about the GOP agenda?  That is the question.

Some adjustment in this tax is a good idea and everybody knows it.  If the Rs could bring themselves to detach such a proposal from the more wild-eyed bits of their current gibberish, it would probably pass fairly quickly and even with some D votes.  Bundled in with the favourite fantasies of Speaker Jellyspine, President LIttlefingers, and Distinguished Majority Leader Yertle the Turtle, it will die an inglorious death.  Some days I am tired of being a Republican.  Increasingly these days run from very early Sunday morning to very late Saturday night.  I suppose one sticks with it because the Ds are even stupider, if such a thing is possible.

Obviously, I'm not particularly confident this will happen. The tax reform is already a challenge, with the House and Senate having different priorities for the new tax bill. And with the inclusion of the ACA mandate repeal, this becomes even more challenging. Right now, neither bill would pass a "Byrd bath" in the Senate to ensure compliance with reconciliation procedures, which further complicates the process, especially if the Senate passes their version and it goes to conference.  Beyond all this, the proposed bills are not very popular at the moment. The GOP made it clear that the impetus for this push is to appease its donor base, which, news flash, are the people who would most benefit form either of these bills. And with the targeting of blue states, this will make it even harder for GOP congressmen in competitive districts to support this effort as currently written in either form.  Putting aside the issues with the tax bills, Congress has some major issues that it's neglecting in favor of the tax push; namely, the FY18 budget. The Continuing Resolution ends on December 8th, and the Dems have significant leverage to force some issues, to include revamping the tax bills, otherwise they can shut down the government. And as the GOP showed during 2013, the Dems can do so without any real consequences at the polls in 2018. Additionally, both parties need to agree to raise the budget caps implemented in the 2011 Budget Control Act by passing a bipartisan budget agreement. Otherwise, failing to do that, sequestration cuts would automatically take effect, cutting over $50 billion from the DOD appropriation and $38 billion from the non-defense appropriations, plus cuts to mandatory spending programs such as Social Security, Medicaid and Medicare. I can't say for sure, but I don't think the GOP would like to have the narrative of not being able to fully fund the government, particularly DOD and national security. The budget environment is not favorable to the GOP at the moment, and once the bills get scored by CBO (before or after voted on in the chambers before conference), the outlook is likely to be even more bleak for passing comprehensive tax legislation. Of course, the GOP could ignore the warning signs and assume that it will already be voted out of power in 2018, so damn the electorate and pass the legislation it wants. But self-interest is a powerful motivator, so I'm going to assume (for now) that some GOP members actually want to remain in Congress.
